utterances: I'm not too bad, and I'm glad to be with you, Mike.
Well, it's good to have you.
You're up there in Manchester, New Hampshire?
Yes, I am, and in what is not quite sunny but remarkably warm Manchester, New Hampshire.
Oh, you'll take it.
Maybe it's a little different from New Hampshire primaries in the past.
But, you know, I don't have to tell you, Ron, that you know that John F.
Kennedy's father said that he was going to sell his son like a box of soap flakes, I think is the quote.
Has a lot changed since that election, when Joe Kennedy was talking about his son like he was a product?
I lost my husband last year to ALS - Lou Gehrig's disease.
Moyer would like more attention paid to the needs of LGBT seniors.
Well, the marketing aspect of politics has only become more intense since Joe Kennedy's day.
Of course, at that point, television was just coming into its own and had not yet come to campaign dominance.
But of course, since then, it has become the principal instrument by which all political candidates at this level disseminate their views and contest with other candidates.
So television runs the show.
A lot of people, I think, feel that our entire presidential nominating and electing process has essentially become a long-running TV reality show.

Do you think that the campaigns themselves if, in a moment of honesty, would they tell you what we have to do is position a candidate who the people like the most as a person, or would they tell you what we have to do is think about a set of issues that the people will respond to the best?
Normally, you would get an intense argument, a pitched battle over that very question.

But not right now because in this 24 or 48, 72-hour period, we are seeing one of those phenomena that comes along every so many decades in American politics, where a particular individual for a certain period of time -very hard to predict how long it will be - captures the imagination of a large proportion of the voters, at least in a few states in the primary process.

Whether or not it'll be a national phenomenon is yet to be seen, but Barack Obama is ripping through New Hampshire much the way he did in the final days of the Iowa campaign, and vastly increasing the number of people who would consider voting for him tomorrow in the primary, or consider voting for him in November for president, or just be able to imagine him being president.
And is he a collection of issues, or is he a cut of his jib type appeal to his candidacy?
Well, with all respect to his views on the issues, and I'm not saying he hasn't many views on many issues and plans and proposals for things to do, but that's not the sum of his candidacy.

In fact, his candidacy is all about transcending that sort of talk and transcending the kind of laundry list of things that you want to do and change that most politicians like to rely on or tend to rely on, and instead, offering something that is, well, it's more music than it is prose.
It's more a kind of almost mysterious appeal to some portion of people that is not entirely rational.
Now, it's not said, in a lack of respect, for the rational aspects of Barack Obama's campaign.
The man is a trained lawyer.
He's a United States senator.
He can make a rational argument.
But what he is doing on the stump right now that's making him a phenomenon goes well beyond that.
All right.
Let's see what - here's another perspective.
I think, Veronica, from Kensington, California, are you there?
I'm here.
How do you make up your mind, Veronica?
You know, I have to agree with your guest today.
It's completely a gut-feeling reaction for me, particularly, being a woman.
I - for me, that's all I see.
The importance of electing a woman president transcends every issue.
Would you say no matter what woman were running, or this particular woman…
(unintelligible)
…Hillary Clinton embodies it for you?
Yes, absolutely.
And I think I've been surprised at how little that's been spoken to.
I mean, the breaking the glass ceiling is of utmost importance.
And I, you know, that to me, is unprecedental(ph).
All right.
Thanks for the call, Veronica.
So Ron Elving, you have someone there who wants to vote for a woman.
Have you heard explicitly people saying, I want to vote for a black candidate or a candidate of mixed race like Barack Obama is?

Maybe not so much in Iowa and New Hampshire, where the population of people who are non-white is quite small, but I think there will be people, who in the course of these primaries, want to vote for Barack Obama based on his racial background.
I do agree with the caller.

I am surprised that there has not been more discussion of the importance for women, for the history of women in America, the history of women in all world politics, of the notion that the Democrats have come quite close, have had a front-runner for months who is a woman and who is bidding fair to become the first woman president of the United States.
That got a lot of attention around the world.
And if she does stumble in these early events, and if she is frustrated in her effort to become president, many people will see that in terms of sexual politics, gender politics.
Okay.
Hang on, Ron, hang on, Anne, with the New Hampshire primary right around the corner.
We are talking about how people actually make up their minds on Election Day.
Let us know what you're thinking.
We're taking your calls at 800-989-8255 or send us an e-mail at talk@npr.org.
I'm Mike Pesca.
It's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Mike Pesca in Washington.
You've heard a lot about candidates wooing undecided voters, and you can follow their efforts in the final day before the New Hampshire primaries with a video on our Web site npr.org.
But what actually pushes an undecided to decide?
We're talking about the mysterious chemistry that goes into that moment of truth this hour.
My guests are NPR senior Washington editor Ron Elving and Ann Mack.
She's the director of trend spotting at the advertising agency JWT.
And of course, we want to hear from you.
Give us a call at 800-989-8255.
Our e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
You can read what other listeners have to say at our blog, npr.org/blogofthenation.
And Anne Mack, you heard from a few callers who took umbrage at the offense that anything other than issues would make them decide.
And what I want to know is when you explicitly ask something, is it issues or people?
Do you get a different answer than the different ways of polling that you have of getting at that conundrum, the person versus the politics?
Yes.
Actually, we ask them what they think their actions would be, and then we also ask them what they think the other actions of other people will be.
And usually, it lies somewhere in between.
I'll give you an example.
We had asked a question about whether spouses, a candidate spouse, would enter into their decision about who they would vote for.
And that's compared to 34 percent in 1995.
Well, a whopping 77 percent said they believe it had played into other people's votes.
But a minority said it didn't play into their own.
So what does it mean?
It means that likely, their real actions falls somewhere in between.
Yeah.
It's sort of like, the question, are you affected by negative ads?
No. Are other people?
Oh, yeah.
Sadly so.
Of course.
Of course.
So it's somewhere in between.
That's where the truth lies.
Rebecca(ph) in Brattleboro, Vermont.
So maybe she's crossed state lines to check out a primary event rites.
It seems as though voters will vote for whoever appears nicest.
They don't want fighting.
The guy you'd want to have a beer with, the most inspirational, seems to win.
This is also why Congress's approval rating is so low, people hate watching sausage being made.
Ron Elving, what about that nice factor?
You know, this is one of the real mysteries to me, about this process, because we know for certain, because we've seen it so many times, that negative advertising works.
But people don't want to be reminded that it works.
They don't like to see it in process.
They don't want to watch people fight.
But they will definitely change their votes.
We've seen it again and again when negative information about a candidate is conveyed to them by negative ads…
Do you think of it …
…television ads, fliers, the works.
Ron, do you think it's the manner of conveying it?
I ask that because I was watching the ABC Republican debate the other night.

And Mitt Romney made a reference to his stance and Mike Huckabee, who's a funny guy, came in with which stance, meaning that Mitt Romney has had a couple of them, and it got a chuckle from the audience.
Now, if that had been said in a different way or with a sneer, maybe people would chafe at the Mike Huckabee message.
I think Huckabee has gotten away with a good deal of counterpunching by couching it in humor and by essentially portraying it as counterpunching.
In other words, I'm simply defending myself when I call you a flip-flopper who's dishonest and doesn't tell the truth to the voters, that sort of thing.
At the same time, when you're doing it in a campaign commercial, it really has a kind of art to it.
You need to be effective and get the point across without being too nasty.

And of course, with the law change that requires each candidate to identify himself or herself at the end of each ad, you're not going to be able slip this ad by without people realizing that it's the work of your campaign.
Chris(ph) from Louisville, Kentucky.
Welcome to the conversation, Chris.
Hi.
Hi.
